data.text: @nntaleb The problem with ideology and intransigent politicians is they become de facto binary classifier … gets 49% of classification wrong when fed fractional data

5/ The two cards that the classifier got wrong were false positives. This was quite surprising as they look obviously fake. I noticed that defects in fake cards can be quite diverse, the machine might not have seen these variations of fake cards to pick them out as fake. https://t.co/bg0T3g049t

4/ Was really surprised that the model, trained on only 373 images, was able to classifier cards as real or fake with a high accuracy of 97.4% (78 cards in test set). Hope I didn’t make any rookie mistakes? Test set is separate from my train set so there shouldn’t be overfitting. https://t.co/fNkduaFz7P

In this meetup, Mansi Aggarwal  will discuss a paper titled as “A Comparative Study Using Geometric and Vertical Profile Features Derived From Airborne LIDAR for Classifying Tree Genera” and how she used the approaches mentioned in this paper to build a tree species classifier.

3/ I used area under the ROC curve to assess the performance of my model. Somehow ended up with a perfect classifier ROC curve, which made me kind of uneasy – decided to predict my test data anyhow. https://t.co/Sxn3ptpiiy

You use the transformer machinery (self-attention, positional embeddings) to embed metadata along with actions (both historical and the potential action you want to calculate the score for).

You then feed it all to the standard classifier head and voila!

So with NCF we can model non-linear interactions between entities

embeddings ➡️ couple of non-linear layers ➡️ high-level representation ➡️ score

But what if we wanted our model to rely on concrete details as well?

Say loyal_cust = 1

Feed them directly to the classifier head!

For reference, and AUC (area under of the curve) of .5 means a model is no better than a coin flip, and an AUC of 1 means your model is perfect (impossible for obvious reasons). The .7-.8 is what is considered a "fair" classifier, and I will gladly accept that

@thesoyjim @asmae_toumi Nope. It's called a Skidmore-Turner classifier. I gave a paper on it at the 1992 AAG Annual Meeting, where I did an ecological land classification using physiographic data.😆 Most of this stuff is 1980s applied maths.

@thesoyjim @asmae_toumi Yup. I remember meeting the CTO of an anti-spam company, and I said, let me guess, you are training a nonparametric classifier in a multi dimensional feature space and normalizing by the sample size, then looking up vectors in it. He says, "You read my patent."...

A subobject classifier represents the "fibrations" with fibres "of at most on element": Hence you can either think of a subobject in a topos as 

m : A -> B, m monic

or as 

χm : B → Ω

(monic implies the fibre over any point of B has at most one element) 7/
